conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on blocks A and B, denoting their masses as m_A and m_B.
Block B is pushed by a horizontal force and is in close contact with block A.
Block B is just about to slide down, and block A is just about to slip.
The coefficient of kinetic friction between A and B is μ_1, and between A and the ground is μ_2.
Frictional force f_AB is at its maximum static value, equal to kinetic friction: f_AB = μ_1 N_AB.
Normal force N_AB is equal to the weight of block B: N_AB = m_B g.
Frictional force f_AB is μ_1 m_B g.
Frictional force f_A is at its maximum static value, equal to kinetic friction: f_A = μ_2 N_A.
Normal force N_A is equal to the combined weight of blocks A and B: N_A = (m_A + m_B) g.
Frictional force f_A is μ_2 (m_A + m_B) g.
For block B to be just about to slide down, F = f_AB = μ_1 m_B g.
For block A to be just about to slip, N_BA = f_A = μ_2 (m_A + m_B) g.
Since N_BA = m_B g, m_B g = μ_2 (m_A + m_B) g.
Solving for the mass ratio: m_B = μ_2 (m_A + m_B).
The mass ratio of block A to block B is m_A/m_B = (1 - μ_2)/μ_2.
